content.title: Labor’s ‘back door’ to restart boats - The Australian
content.desc: Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton has accused the Labor party of supporting a policy that will end offshore detention of asylum seekers and restart the boats. Mr Dutton has hit out at the opposition’s support of a bill to urgently transfer sick asylum seekers on Manus Island and Nauru to Australia, saying border protection would “collapse” under Labor and “the boats will restart”. “What Labor is proposing here is a back doorway to end regional processing. That is one of the three limbs that has stopped the boats,” Mr Dutton told reporters in Brisbane on Saturday. The comments come after La...

content.title: International students deported in crackdown - The Advertiser
content.desc: The Home Affairs Department is reviewing on a weekly basis lists of international students to make sure the system is not being rorted by foreigners wanting work rights in Australia. It checks up on students who are not longer enrolled in a course, where their last recorded study was more than two months ago but there was still more than six months until their visa expired. MORE NEWS Hells Angels bikie killer to get minute of freedom Dumped: Labor disendorses MP Emma Husar Man charged over alleged ‘peeping Tom’ incident It comes as the government is preparing to overhaul the visa system as ...

content.title: Opinion: In their topsy-turvy Liberal universe, MPs take a 'socialist' tack - ABC News
content.desc: By Michelle Grattan In the topsy-turvy Liberal universe, just when the right is trying to tighten its grip on the throat of the party, the Government is haring off to the left, with this week's legislation to allow it to break up recalcitrant energy companies. As former deputy Liberal leader Julie Bishop — who as a backbencher has become very forthright — said in the Coalition party room on Tuesday, "this is not orthodox Liberal policy". Ms Bishop canvassed the danger of sovereign risk. To find a rationale for a frolic into what in other circumstances the Liberals would no doubt denounce as...

content.title: Labor wasn't prepared to just leave encryption laws hanging: Shorten - ABC News
content.desc: Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says legitimate concerns remain over the encrypted message access bill, but that he was not prepared to leave the legislation hanging over the summer break. Key points: - Bill Shorten said Labor did not want to expose more risks to national security in the interim - Labor will seek to review encryption legislation in February - Scott Morrison has accused the Greens and Labor of using encryption laws as a tool to water down border protections Labor had planned to amend the Government's legislation — which has repeatedly been described as flawed — only t...

content.title: Labor passes encryption bill as Morrison dodges lower house vote on Nauru - The Guardian
content.desc: Labor has waved through the Morrison government’s encryption bill, capping off a day of high political drama where the prime minister managed to avoid a de facto vote of no confidence in the Coalition in the lower house. A Senate filibuster thwarted efforts by the non-government parties to pass legislation that would have removed refugees from Nauru and Manus Island, forcing a situation where an incumbent government would have lost a substantive vote for the first time in almost 90 years. With Scott Morrison’s authority on the line on the final parliamentary sitting day for 2018, the govern...

content.title: Scott Morrison vows to ‘fight’ Nauru bill (full speech) | ABC News - ABC News
content.desc: The Prime Minister has ramped up his attack on Labor, as he faces the prospect of defeat on a bill to get more refugees off Nauru and Manus Island. content.title: Crossbench MPs flex political muscle to pressure Government over refugee children - ABC News
content.desc: The Prime Minister has ramped up his attack on Labor, as he faces the prospect of defeat on a bill to get more refugees off Nauru and Manus Island. Key points: - Crossbench MPs pressuring Government to remove all refugee children from Nauru and Manus Island - Morrison vows to block all attempts to change asylum seeker policies, citing national security - Government offered national security and Operation Sovereign Borders briefings to crossbenchers Labor, the Greens and crossbenchers have teamed up to legislate faster medical treatment for refugees in offshore processing. The Government is ...

content.title: Australia’s global clout dented by political instability - Financial Times
content.desc: When Scott Morrison met Angela Merkel at the G20 last weekend, the German chancellor was photographed flicking through her briefing notes on the new Australian prime minister. Ms Merkel was not alone in her bewilderment. Her G20 counterparts were also struggling to keep up with the brutal “revolving door” leadership culture that characterises recent politics Down Under, where there have been five prime ministers in five years. Donald Trump was more direct when he met Mr Morrison, who replaced Malcolm Turnbull following a leadership coup in August. He simply asked Mr Morrison what had happen...
